description.p: A cloud-based IaaS environment.
An example of three customers leveraging an authorized SaaS, which is running on an authorized IaaS.
In this example, the IaaS SSP specifies customer responsibilities for certain controls.
The SaaS must address these for the control to be fully satisfied.
The SaaS provider may either implement these directly, or pass the responsiblity on to their customers. Often both are necessary.
For any given control, the IaaS SSP must describe:

ol.li: HOW the IaaS is directly satisfying the control
WHAT responsibilities are left for the IaaS customer to implement. (The IaaS customer is the SaaS.)

description.p: For any given control, the SaaS SSP must describe:

ol.li: WHAT is being inherited from the underlying IaaS
HOW the SaaS is directly satisfying the control.
WHAT responsibilities are left for the SaaS customer to implement. (The SaaS customers are Cust-A, B and C)

component.title: IaaS Audit, Logging, and Incident Response Procedure

set-parameter.value: Fails over to alternate centralized logging component; Store logs locally/cache them; Overwrite oldest record.

description.p: The centralized logging component is configured to alert the IaaS SOC of audit processing failure via email to soc@big-iaas.cloud.
All components communicate with the centralized logging server and the IaaS SOC via a private, dedicated administrative network.
The routers are configured to alert the IaaS SOC, if they are unable to transmit logs, via email to soc@big-iaas.cloud.
If routers lose network connectivity (thus are unable to notify the IaaS SOC), their off-line status will be recognized and alerted as described in control XX-#.
The switches are configured to alert the IaaS SOC, if they are unable to transmit logs, via email to soc@big-iaas.cloud.
If switches lose network connectivity (thus are unable to notify the IaaS SOC), their off-line status will be recognized and alerted as described in control XX-#.
The firewalls are configured to alert the IaaS SOC, if they are unable to transmit logs, via email to soc@big-iaas.cloud.
If firewalls lose network connectivity (thus are unable to notify the IaaS SOC), their off-line status will be recognized and alerted as described in control XX-#.
The Hypervisor is configured to alert the IaaS SOC, if they are unable to transmit logs, via email to soc@big-iaas.cloud.

As described in the IaaS Audit, Logging, and Incident Response Procedure, the IaaS SOC Team will allert each customer's designated POC of any logging outages that impact a customer's ability to maintain logging.
The customer must configure all virtual components to alert appropriate customer POCs in the event of audit processing errors.
The centralized logging component logs any failures within its datastores if possible.
In accordance with the IaaS Audit, Logging, and Incident Response Procedure, the SOC performs a failover to the alternate centralized logging capability.

Routers are configured to store logs locally until the centralized logging capability is restored. In the event of reaching local log capacity each router is configured to overwrite the oldest logs first.

Switches are configured to store logs locally until the centralized logging capability is restored. In the event of reaching local log capacity each switch is configured to overwrite the oldest logs first.

Firewalls are configured to store logs locally until the centralized logging capability is restored. In the event of reaching local log capacity each firewall is configured to overwrite the oldest logs first.

The Hypervisor is configured to store logs locally until the centralized logging capability is restored. In the event of reaching local log capacity the hypervisor is configured to overwrite the oldest logs first.

The IaaS customer (SaaS Provider) must configure all virtual components to store logs locally until centralized logging can be restored. Customer must also ensure virtual components overwrite oldest logs first in the event local log stores reach capacity.
